subject: Art
title: Harsh vs Soft Light
description: How light source size determines shadow quality and mood.

hook.text: Noon sun: sharp, dark shadows. Overcast day: gentle, diffused shadows. The difference isn't brightness â€” it's the apparent size of the light source relative to the subject. Size controls shadow quality.

buildup.text: Small/distant light source (bare bulb, midday sun) = hard shadows with sharp edges. Large/close light source (cloudy sky, big window, softbox) = soft shadows with gradual transitions.

discovery.text: Soft light flatters faces (conceals skin texture, wraps around features). Hard light creates drama (deep shadows, strong contrast, defined edges). Neither is better â€” they serve different moods.

twist.text: A cloudy day is a photographer's studio: the entire sky becomes a giant softbox. Fashion photographers pay thousands for lighting setups that clouds provide for free. Overcast isn't 'bad weather' â€” it's free soft light.

climax.text: Photograph a face in direct sunlight (hard), then move to open shade (soft). The hard light creates drama but reveals every pore and wrinkle. The soft light flatters and evens the skin. Match the light to the mood.

punchline.text: Hard light tells truth. Soft light tells kindness. Both are honest â€” just different kinds.

quiz.question: What determines whether light produces hard or soft shadows?
options: The apparent size of the light source relative to the subject
